Local Colleges Join Hopkins
For Inter-Campus Programs
Trips in Baltimore-DC Area Planned
by Weijen Chang
It may come as a surprise to
some Hopkins students, but there
are other colleges in the
Baltimore area besides Hopkins.
Two colleges in the Baltimore
area, in association with Hopkins
Organization for Programming,
have decided to attempt to promote this fact by forming, within
the past year, the Inter-Campus
Programming Board.
Composed of student representatives from Hopkins, Goucher
College, and the College of Notre
Dame, the ICPB, in the words of
HOP chairman Nancy Moeder, is
trying to "increase interest and
participation in events on other
campuses . . . and to plan big
events between all three colleges,
where the three colleges would
share programming expenses of
any event."
Student Activities Commission
Chairman Dave Shade, who,
along with Moeder, has gone to
ICPB meetings consistently, said
that Goucher and Notre Dame
were both quite interested in the
ICPB.
The ICPB meetings are held biweekly at all three colleges. At
Hopkins they are held on
Wednesdays following the Student Council meetings.
According to Moeder and
Shade, the ICPB itself was conceived before a party last
November that Notre Dame and
Hopkins co-sponsored. Both
Moeder and Shade do not agree,
however, on whether Hopkins or
Notre Dame had the original concept of the ICPB.
It was originated, said Shade,
when "we realized it was stupid
for them to have a big party and
for us to have a big party the same
night."
Although the ties established by
the ICPB are informal, said
Moeder and Shade, some things
have already been accomplished.
The ICPB has already established "clearing houses" on each
campus in order to facilitate the
distribution of posters and flyers
publicizing events on other
campuses.
Another proposal that the ICPB
is promoting is a shuttle running
between Notre Dame and
Hopkins. The ICPB has,
however, already experienced
some setbacks. One failure, mentioned Moeder and Shade, was
the demise of a plan to rent out
the Port Welcome in Baltimore
harbor as part of an inter-campus
party.
Shade and Moeder also spoke
of the possibility of "plugging into 'coordinate' events between
schools." Two events sponsored
by Goucher that Hopkins students
might be able to "plug into" in
the near future are a trip to the
Georgetown-Pittsburgh college
basketball game on February 18
at Landover, Md., and an overnight ski trip to Ski Roundtop in
Pennsylvania on February 20.
Other "coordinate" events in
Baltimore City, said Moeder and

Shade, might include a
"Preakness Party" before a trip
to Pimlico Racetrack, trips to
Baltimore Blast games, renting
Winchester's in downtown
Baltimore for an inter-campus
party, and cultural events such as
trips to the Smithsonian in
Washington D.C., to the
Baltimore Museum of Art and the
Walters Art Gallery; and to the
Baltimore Symphony Orchestra,
Lyric Theater, and Kennedy
Center for the Performing Arts.
Shade and Moeder also mentioned the possibility of expan-

ding participation among the
three colleges during Orientation,
and the possibility of a joint
leadership program among the
three.
Other possibilities may be considered, said Moeder and Shade,
who assert their need for suggestions and support.
Shade concluded, "We're using all three campuses, which
should lower expenses, while
bringing in people from all three
colleges, increasing the variety of
people there. . .There's a lot
possible here."

The Hopkins News-Letter Committee Reports
A Courageous Document
On September 30, University President
Steven Muller announced the formation of
an Ad Hoc Committee to investigate the
status of freedom of expression at Hopkins
in the wake of the arrest of fourteen anti, Apartheid shanty-builders. But he may well
have opened the Administration to much
more criticism than he ever expected in
those turbulent days last semester.
This week, the Committee on Freedom
of Expression, chaired by Richard
Flathman of the department of political
science, released the first draft of its report
which harshly criticizes the University for
its "aberrant action" in the arrest of shantybuilders and demolition of a protest shanty. The report also proposes a Statement
of Principle and Practice that goes far
beyond present University policy in defending and "fostering" freedom of
expression.
In both its substance and language, the
report is undoubtedly one of the most
courageous documents to emerge from the
University in recent memory and is a credit
to the University and the committee that
produced it.
In forming the report (printed in its entirety elsewhere on these pages) the Committee on Freedom of Expression made a
sharp departure form the traditional University line at a number of points.
First, the report insists that the University must protect and foster all forms of expression "so long as neither physical injury to persons nor significant damage to
property is inflicted." Until now, University officials have argued that potential
threats to personal safety (like fires and
shanty-attacks) outweigh rights to freedom
of expression. The report seems to have
taken the contrary position.
Furthermore, the report stresses the
responsibility of the University to "make
special efforts" to accomodate expression
of ideas particularly when those ideas are
repugnant to some members of the
community.
Beyond its nearly unconditional defense
of freedom of expression, the report of the

Committee also calls for a rather sweeping procedural change in dealing with
freedom of expression issues.
During last semester's confrontations, the
Executive Committee of the Board of
Trustees took the lead in setting University policy with regard to freedom of speech
issues. It was the Executive Committee, for
example, that "outlawed" the construction
of shanties in a curt policy statement in the
Gazette. Later, the Executive Committee
reversed its shanty-ban in a late-night
meeting after the arrest of fourteen
protestors.
The Committee on Freedom of Expression, however, recommends that the
authority to deal with freedom of speech
issues be vested not in the Executive Committee, but rather in the Academic Council.
Specifically, the Committee urges the
Academic Council to form an "Ad Hoc Committee of faculty and students" when difficulty arises "in the implementation of the
principle of freedom of expression."
The procedural change recommended by
the Committee on Freedom of Expression
is an important one. If enacted, it would
take the authority to deal with problems of
freedom of expression out of the hands of
a committee which has traditionally been
somewhat aloof(and rightly so) from the
day to day happenings on campus, and
place that authority in a much more accessible body.
Furthermore, the procedure recommended by the Committee on Freedom of Expression would allow, for once, real opportunities for student input into the resolution
of problems relating to freedom of
expression.
On the whole, the Statement of Principle and Practice outlined in the Committee's report merits prompt consideration.
Like the Committee on Freedom of Expression, we urge the Academic Council, President and Board of Trustees to adopt the
Statement of Principle and Practice formally as a policy of the University. And, we
congratulate the Committee on Freedom of
Expression for a job well done.

Image-Polishing
It's clear that this semester has gotten off
to a less dramatic start than last semester.
In the absence of arrests, trials and protests,
the new semester hardly seems thrilling.
Nevertheless, important work is waiting to
be done. It's time Council started worrying about it.
Last week, we urged Council to use the
relative calm of the new semester to set a
detailed agenda of priorities. We suggested
that the SAC seals, social programming and
security would be appropriate for such an
agenda. Undoubtedly, there are other issues
which merit attention like responding to the
conclusions of the Committee on Free Expression and redefining the role of the
COC.
Nevertheless, despite the range of work
waiting to be done, Council used its most
recent session not to address the work at
hand but to debate, of all things, its own

image in the media.
During an hour and a half long meeting,
discussion was devoted almost exclusively
to News-Letter coverage of Council's activities and to criticisms made on these
pages last week. Council concluded that the
News-Letter has created "negative feelings" and decided to investigate the
possibility of writing its own reports of SC
activities—presumably those reports will be
nicer.
We hope that after its lengthy debate
Council has now exhausted its interest in
itself and its image and will turn to the more
serious and productive business of serving
its constituency. We look forward to
debates of more worthy issues in weeks to
come. Perhaps with a docket of such issues
scheduled for debate, Council won't have
to worry about attracting a quorum of its
members to its meetings.

Finite and Infinite Games
By James P. Carse, The Free
Press, $13.95, 149 pp.
If you were to try to step back
from the world and objectively
speculate about mankind, it might
be convenient to categorize people. Certainly you would make
some generalizations which
would require typing (or
stereotyping) individuals to capture human nature. If you sought
to suggest how to achieve a "better" world, you might contrast
your depiction of humanity with
a "better" person. This individual may or may not exist in
today's world. It may be
altogether possible that this person already exists within each of
us; he is, however, hidden, or
suppressed.
Given this intention, it would
be difficult to do a more comprehensive job than James P.
Carse in his Finite and Infinite
Games. Carse indeed sets up a
contrast between the players of
finite games and infinite games.
Through this contrast he can
theorize on the human condition
and its manifestations in today's
world.
"Games" is a playful
term for manners of living.
Carse's "games" metaphor is effective because he can correlate
his observations of board games
and athletic competitions, which
describe aspects of a finite game,
with "real life' (although we attempt to distinguish the two).
The finite game is one of conquest, of power. Its players are
desirous of trophies which attest
to their strength, thereby securing their position amongst others
in society. The finite game ends
with a victor and a loser. Whereas
the victor is duly memorialized,
the loser is just as duly forgotten.
As evident as the flaws are with
this style of living--perhaps the
two greatest are the lack of interaction among people and the
great stifling of the human mind's
creative genius--Carse's most interesting point is the contradictory

life of the finite player. The finite
player lives to end the game with
his own conquest. It is played so
that the conquest will be
remembered—it is a game of the
past. In sum the finite game is
played to end itself. Further, by
seeking trophies and titles, the
finite player hopes to secure a
degree of immortality. As Carse
describes, this search is a
supreme example of the contradictoriness of finite play. It
means living life in order to
secure "a life one cannot live."
By contrast the infinite game is
one in which the players do not
compete against each other, but
rather interact with each other. It
is not a game in which there is a
winner and loser, nor is it a game
which ends and which would,
therefore, be remembered as a
thing of the past. The infinite
game opens up the future, opening up new possibilities by bringing together individuals.
Using this framework, Carse
describes many aspects of society: our sexuality, creativity,
machinery, language. I appreciated this attention to the
details of our culture, though he
doesn't move too much beyond
his general point, which is made
early on in the book.
Another problem is one which
I feel is almost inevitable in the
sort of "bettering the world"
book that this is: practicalities.
Honest communication is always
desirable, as well as is a less
competitive world, and yet one
has to ask where this restructuring of the world begins and what
the individual can and should do.
However, it is not fair to the
book to look at it purely from a
practical perspective. This is not
simply a "let's be better people"
work. It is a well-thought out
discourse which does particularly well when it tries to be a little
clever. The broad theme of the
finite vs. infinite games is well
constructed, albeit not completely original. In addition, Carse's
discussion of myths vs. history is
very interesting. History suffers
the same limitations as does the
finite game. Historical periods

More specifically, do men and

ofIllinois came to the conclusion

the woman's "natural timidity
and delicacy" she was unfit for

many types of work, most notably
the practice of law. Karen Berger
Morello's Invisible Bar: The
Woman Lawyer in America intelligently discusses the barriers
and accomplishments women
have had in trying to gain access
to the obstinate sphere of law.
Morello traces the role women
have had in reforming the legal
profession and even in shaping
the legal system.
Herself a lawyer and historian,
Morello documents and explains
the impact of women's legal firsts
such as the first woman lawyer in
the New World, the first black

notes that the first woman lawyer
in America, "Gentleman
Margaret Brent," a barrister who
arrived in Maryland in 1615 and
also cousin to Lord Baltimore,
was the only woman lawyer in
the New World until 1869. The
real struggle for women to enter
the legal profession was an
outgrowth of the suffrage movement. An early leader of the suffrage movement, Myra Bradwell,
was the first person to challenge
a legal bar's admission standards.

After completing all the requirements for admission except
formal application, Bradwell petitioned the Chicago Bar for entrance. She was refused. She
brought the rejection to trial; and
the case went to the Supreme
Court, which delivered a questionable decision that the bar
could reject an application on the
grounds of sex.
The finality of the ruling on
Bradwell prompted a brief outcry
from America's left, but many in
the mainstream felt that women
should stay out of the legal profession. Popular ideas such as:
"Women in the courtroom would
sway the opinions of jurists only

with a glance," "Women in law

should be allowed to have a

general should not be lawyers.

schools told women law students

The Hopkins News-Letter Committee Reports
A Courageous Document
On September 30, University President
Steven Muller announced the formation of
an Ad Hoc Committee to investigate the
status of freedom of expression at Hopkins
in the wake of the arrest of fourteen anti, Apartheid shanty-builders. But he may well
have opened the Administration to much
more criticism than he ever expected in
those turbulent days last semester.
This week, the Committee on Freedom
of Expression, chaired by Richard
Flathman of the department of political
science, released the first draft of its report
which harshly criticizes the University for
its "aberrant action" in the arrest of shantybuilders and demolition of a protest shanty. The report also proposes a Statement
of Principle and Practice that goes far
beyond present University policy in defending and "fostering" freedom of
expression.
In both its substance and language, the
report is undoubtedly one of the most
courageous documents to emerge from the
University in recent memory and is a credit
to the University and the committee that
produced it.
In forming the report (printed in its entirety elsewhere on these pages) the Committee on Freedom of Expression made a
sharp departure form the traditional University line at a number of points.
First, the report insists that the University must protect and foster all forms of expression "so long as neither physical injury to persons nor significant damage to
property is inflicted." Until now, University officials have argued that potential
threats to personal safety (like fires and
shanty-attacks) outweigh rights to freedom
of expression. The report seems to have
taken the contrary position.
Furthermore, the report stresses the
responsibility of the University to "make
special efforts" to accomodate expression
of ideas particularly when those ideas are
repugnant to some members of the
community.
Beyond its nearly unconditional defense
of freedom of expression, the report of the

Committee also calls for a rather sweeping procedural change in dealing with
freedom of expression issues.
During last semester's confrontations, the
Executive Committee of the Board of
Trustees took the lead in setting University policy with regard to freedom of speech
issues. It was the Executive Committee, for
example, that "outlawed" the construction
of shanties in a curt policy statement in the
Gazette. Later, the Executive Committee
reversed its shanty-ban in a late-night
meeting after the arrest of fourteen
protestors.
The Committee on Freedom of Expression, however, recommends that the
authority to deal with freedom of speech
issues be vested not in the Executive Committee, but rather in the Academic Council.
Specifically, the Committee urges the
Academic Council to form an "Ad Hoc Committee of faculty and students" when difficulty arises "in the implementation of the
principle of freedom of expression."
The procedural change recommended by
the Committee on Freedom of Expression
is an important one. If enacted, it would
take the authority to deal with problems of
freedom of expression out of the hands of
a committee which has traditionally been
somewhat aloof(and rightly so) from the
day to day happenings on campus, and
place that authority in a much more accessible body.
Furthermore, the procedure recommended by the Committee on Freedom of Expression would allow, for once, real opportunities for student input into the resolution
of problems relating to freedom of
expression.
On the whole, the Statement of Principle and Practice outlined in the Committee's report merits prompt consideration.
Like the Committee on Freedom of Expression, we urge the Academic Council, President and Board of Trustees to adopt the
Statement of Principle and Practice formally as a policy of the University. And, we
congratulate the Committee on Freedom of
Expression for a job well done.

Image-Polishing
It's clear that this semester has gotten off
to a less dramatic start than last semester.
In the absence of arrests, trials and protests,
the new semester hardly seems thrilling.
Nevertheless, important work is waiting to
be done. It's time Council started worrying about it.
Last week, we urged Council to use the
relative calm of the new semester to set a
detailed agenda of priorities. We suggested
that the SAC seals, social programming and
security would be appropriate for such an
agenda. Undoubtedly, there are other issues
which merit attention like responding to the
conclusions of the Committee on Free Expression and redefining the role of the
COC.
Nevertheless, despite the range of work
waiting to be done, Council used its most
recent session not to address the work at
hand but to debate, of all things, its own

image in the media.
During an hour and a half long meeting,
discussion was devoted almost exclusively
to News-Letter coverage of Council's activities and to criticisms made on these
pages last week. Council concluded that the
News-Letter has created "negative feelings" and decided to investigate the
possibility of writing its own reports of SC
activities—presumably those reports will be
nicer.
We hope that after its lengthy debate
Council has now exhausted its interest in
itself and its image and will turn to the more
serious and productive business of serving
its constituency. We look forward to
debates of more worthy issues in weeks to
come. Perhaps with a docket of such issues
scheduled for debate, Council won't have
to worry about attracting a quorum of its
members to its meetings.

Finite and Infinite Games
By James P. Carse, The Free
Press, $13.95, 149 pp.
If you were to try to step back
from the world and objectively
speculate about mankind, it might
be convenient to categorize people. Certainly you would make
some generalizations which
would require typing (or
stereotyping) individuals to capture human nature. If you sought
to suggest how to achieve a "better" world, you might contrast
your depiction of humanity with
a "better" person. This individual may or may not exist in
today's world. It may be
altogether possible that this person already exists within each of
us; he is, however, hidden, or
suppressed.
Given this intention, it would
be difficult to do a more comprehensive job than James P.
Carse in his Finite and Infinite
Games. Carse indeed sets up a
contrast between the players of
finite games and infinite games.
Through this contrast he can
theorize on the human condition
and its manifestations in today's
world.
"Games" is a playful
term for manners of living.
Carse's "games" metaphor is effective because he can correlate
his observations of board games
and athletic competitions, which
describe aspects of a finite game,
with "real life' (although we attempt to distinguish the two).
The finite game is one of conquest, of power. Its players are
desirous of trophies which attest
to their strength, thereby securing their position amongst others
in society. The finite game ends
with a victor and a loser. Whereas
the victor is duly memorialized,
the loser is just as duly forgotten.
As evident as the flaws are with
this style of living--perhaps the
two greatest are the lack of interaction among people and the
great stifling of the human mind's
creative genius--Carse's most interesting point is the contradictory

life of the finite player. The finite
player lives to end the game with
his own conquest. It is played so
that the conquest will be
remembered—it is a game of the
past. In sum the finite game is
played to end itself. Further, by
seeking trophies and titles, the
finite player hopes to secure a
degree of immortality. As Carse
describes, this search is a
supreme example of the contradictoriness of finite play. It
means living life in order to
secure "a life one cannot live."
By contrast the infinite game is
one in which the players do not
compete against each other, but
rather interact with each other. It
is not a game in which there is a
winner and loser, nor is it a game
which ends and which would,
therefore, be remembered as a
thing of the past. The infinite
game opens up the future, opening up new possibilities by bringing together individuals.
Using this framework, Carse
describes many aspects of society: our sexuality, creativity,
machinery, language. I appreciated this attention to the
details of our culture, though he
doesn't move too much beyond
his general point, which is made
early on in the book.
Another problem is one which
I feel is almost inevitable in the
sort of "bettering the world"
book that this is: practicalities.
Honest communication is always
desirable, as well as is a less
competitive world, and yet one
has to ask where this restructuring of the world begins and what
the individual can and should do.
However, it is not fair to the
book to look at it purely from a
practical perspective. This is not
simply a "let's be better people"
work. It is a well-thought out
discourse which does particularly well when it tries to be a little
clever. The broad theme of the
finite vs. infinite games is well
constructed, albeit not completely original. In addition, Carse's
discussion of myths vs. history is
very interesting. History suffers
the same limitations as does the
finite game. Historical periods
